google_reviews.author: Haleigh Williams
google_reviews.review: Honestly shocked this apartment complex hasnt been sued out of their minds yet. From not deeming apartments unlivable for the sake of insurance so their tenants can have safe dwellings to letting people go weeks without power. I hope the city comes for this complex and every wicked and cruel person involved.

ownerResponse.text: Hello, I don't see that you are a tenant with Village at Baker Creek, so I am wondering if you meant to leave this review elsewhere. If you meant to leave it on Village at Baker Creek website then you have been misinformed about the situation. There were 3 units that had a partial power outage, and it wasn't for weeks. It also wasn't the fault of Village at Baker Creek or staff. The power was shut off for safety issues by PSE and a licensed electrician. Over 100 feet of wire had to be excavated and replaced due to a manufacturing issue that caused the wires in the ground to actually melt. This work took some coordination and time because PSE, the electrician and the City all had to be on site at the same time to get buildings disconnected and then back on again once the work was inspected. You mention the City "coming" for the complex, but the City knew what was happening. The City inspected it all and signed off on it all. Nothing illegal was done. The wires in the ground needed to be replaced. We had to call before digging to get all utilities in ground marked before any work could be done. Vendors don't work 24/7 and every single vendor involved got to the complex as quickly as they possibly could to get the work started. Tenants were notified every step of they way, and even given updates during the weekend while the work was being done. As soon as management was notified that the power needed to be off for an extended time all tenants were contacted with that information. We understand the frustration with it all and wish there was something else that could have been done, but there wasn't and we followed every legal protocol we are required to. Tenants are required to have renters insurance for things like this. In case of an outage and a hotel being needed. The actual  full outage lasted a day and a half. PSE, the electrician and all other vendors work overtime through the weekend to get it repaired in a safe manner for everyone and get the approval from PSE to turn it back on. This was out of our hands completely. We didn't ask for this happen, and certainly hope it never happens again. Unfortunately, things do happen that are out the hands of staff and owners. This situation doesn't make the unit "unlivable" as you claim. We took care of an unsafe wire like we are required to do. Our units are inspected on a regular basis from the City and nothing has ever been deemed unlivable. We hope this clears up the misinformation you were told and the misinformation in this review. Have a great day.

ownerResponse.text:
Hello,

ownerResponse.text: Thank you for the kind words. It was our pleasure to have you live with us. You were fantastic tenants.

google_reviews.author: Nick Rose
google_reviews.review:
Im shocked by the things some people have experienced here. My girlfriend and I have lived here for a year and a half now. We moved in by taking over a lease. While the office did seem a bit disorganized during the lease takeover process, they were very straightforward about what we and the current tenants needed to do to complete the lease takeover. We had no problems whatsoever moving in. In the time that we have lived here, we have never had a poor experience with management. In fact, when the stay at home order began, we became concerned with how we would pay our rent. We emailed management and they simply asked us to pay what we could and that we could arrange the leftover on a payment plan. While that was unnecessary, we were very appreciative that they were willing to help. Overall, everyone will have their own experience, but I suggest that people at least give this company a chance rather than believing some poor google reviews.

Also, whenever we have had issues in our unit, maintenance has always been very prompt and happy to help with whatever we needed. All of our issues were resolved the day of or the following Monday if we reported it over the weekend. It is honestly a pleasure to see the maintenance man around the complex. He always has a smile on his face and a couple jokes to add as well. Of the 3 apartments we have had in Bellingham, Village at Baker Creek has by far been the best experience.

The management, however, were the absolute rudest, the most passive-aggressive, unqualified, unprofessional staff I've EVER had to deal with in all my years of renting. From the constant rude emails, letters, texts and even being screamed at in person by the manager. They also always seemed to "lose" important paperwork/documents.

google_reviews.author: Jos
google_reviews.review:
We have been long time renters and this place has drastically gone down hill since the day we moved in. Ever since we moved in years ago we've been waiting on an ordered item to come in so that they could fix an item in our apartment. Years later, and after constantly bugging the leasing office, we are STILL waiting and the item is "still on order" to present day. Not to mention we have also been waiting on several other items to be fixed since the day we moved in that havent. We've literally just given up on fighting them about it.

If and when you need to fill out a maintenance form the follow up can take around two weeks or more for any response, let alone any work to actually be done. Even then, nothing is genuinely fixed. The maintenance workers slap a bandaid on it and call it good until the minor problem becomes an even bigger problem. A huge reflection on their low budget for maintenance. One time, we were even told to go to Home Depot, buy the item, and fix it ourselves. While I'm sure it's none of the maintenance workers fault directly, and more or less just cruddy management, the complex goes through maintenance workers quicker than a speeding bullet. So by the time that a minor problem becomes a bigger problem the new maintenance worker has no idea what the last one did and just manages to put yet another bandaid on the problem and leaving it for the next guy. It's not just the maintenance workers either. Receptionists here in the leasing office change every two to three months as well, which leads to even more confusion all around. It's a huge mess.

Lastly, for the longest time we were notified in our mail boxes if we received a package. However, since Graeme Dyehouse became apart of management we no longer receive any notification at all. We have had care packages sent to us by family that didn't get picked up for months because of the sudden change in management. No notification at all of this change either. He has been the major downfall to the management here at Village at Baker Creek. Very difficult to work with, rude, and has a "I'm-better-than-you" egotistical complex. If you can manage to, stay away and find a better complex!!!

summary.text:
Good

Village at Baker Creek has received some positive praise from a subset of its tenant base. User reviews have mentioned helpful management in some cases and prompt maintenance services, which are highlighted as positives for the community. For instance, some tenants have reported satisfaction with maintenance requests being resolved swiftly, often the same day or the following day if reported on a weekend. Furthermore, there are acknowledgments of the complex's favorable location near the Bellis Fair mall and its well-maintained site, providing an ostensibly enjoyable living environment for some residents.

Additionally, specific user reviews have mentioned welcoming and friendly interactions with certain staff members, particularly front desk personnel who have offered assistance and eased the lease takeover processes. This demonstrates instances where the staff have had positive interactions and have been accomodating to residents' concerns and requests.

Great

There have been instances where the Village at Baker Creek has shown exceptional service which merits its own accolades. Some reviews indicate that residents have found the property to be tranquil and the management accommodating, especially during challenging times such as the onset of a stay at home order. In this particular scenario, management showed flexibility with rent payments, suggesting an understanding and willingness to support tenants through financial hardships. This gesture of kindness and consideration has been highly appreciated by some individuals.

Bad

Despite the positives, there have been criticisms leveled at Village at Baker Creek that cannot be ignored. User reviews have revealed concerns over the professionalism and consistency of the management staff. Residents have mentioned experiences of unprofessional behavior, including being yelled at and receiving threatening notices. Furthermore, tenants have reported issues around the upkeep of the older units and the parking situation, which appear to be ongoing and unresolved concerns that detract from the quality of living at the complex. The frustration with management's handling of these concerns is evident in the reviews.

In addition, there have been negative experiences related to the return of security deposits where tenants felt that the deductions were unjustified, particularly after leaving the apartment in a clean condition. This has led to a sense of distrust towards the management's practices, as expressed in the detailed accounts of previous tenants. Such experiences underline the need for transparent and fair management-tenant practices.

Ugly

The ugliest side of Village at Baker Creek, as detailed in multiple user reviews, pertains to a perceived lack of empathy, transparency, and professionalism by the property management team. From tenants feeling disrespected and verbally harassed to allegations of mishandled paperwork and miscommunication, there's a theme of deep dissatisfaction with the way the complex is managed. Incidents such as unsolicited entry into apartments and management's seemingly arbitrary enforcement of complex rules paint a bleak picture of respect for tenant rights and privacy.

Further exacerbating the sentiment of discontent are claims of neglecting maintenance issues that compromise the integrity and habitability of living spaces, including the serious allegation of untreated mold growth. Residents feel their feedback and complaints are not adequately addressed, leading to a breakdown in the landlord-tenant relationship. These aspects represent the most critical areas of concern that the management at Village at Baker Creek would need to immediately address to improve tenant relations and the reputation of the property.
